So basically,

Human minds are one of the most complicated things and the rules that govern it are mysterious & elusive.

While the term "psychology" was coined around 16th Century, the practice of science around it was no established until the 1800. The formal definition of psychology has evolved over the last several decades, today we can safely call it the science of behavior and mental processes.


Psychology is one of the most extremely diverse in terms of the questions it proposes, the method it applies and the school of though it contains.

For instance, right around Freud's(1900-1939) time, there were a lot of different schools of thought of about how the study of the human mind should be tackled. Mainly, there were the ideas of structuralism, functionalism and psychoanalysis.

-"Structuralism" in 1879 by Wilhelm Wundt & Edward Bradford Titchener:
"Structuralism" focusses on how patient feel when they do something like watched the sun set, or smell a coffee, or licked a kitten, or whatever.
This relied heavily on introspection and it became too subjective and since it's not possible observe a patient's inner thoughts or feelings, so ultimately, the structuralist school of thought was fairly short-lived.

-"Functionalism" in 1890 by William James:
Focuses on the "function of behavior", why we think and feel and smell and lick, or whatever. This approach of 'functionalism', was based on Charles Darwin's idea that adaptive behaviors are conserved throughout the evolutionary process.


-"Psychoanalysis" in 1900 by Freud:
A radical kernel of Psychoanalysis suggests that "our personalities are shaped by unconscious motives" which mean we are all profoundly affected by mental processes that we are not aware of. Another important part of the "Psychoanalysis" is that "unconscious, the thing below consciousness" is still discover-able. An even though we are not aware of it, we can come to understand it through a therapeutic technique using dreams, projections and free association to root out repressed feelings and gain self insight.
So what Freud was really saying was that "mental disorders could be healed through talk therapy and self-discovery". And this was a really big breakthrough. After "The Interpretations of Dreams", Freud went on to publish over 20 more books and countless papers with an iconic cigar in hand all the while.


-"Behaviorism" by Ivan Pavlov, John B. Watson, and B. F. Skinner:
Behaviorism focuses on the study of observable behavior.
The first half of the 20th Century was dominated by "behaviorism" promoted by Ivan Pavlov, John B. Watson, and B. F. Skinner.

-"Psychodynamic Theories" descendant of Freud's Psychoanalysis:
Psychodynamic Theories focuses on importance of early experiences in shaping the unconscious and how that process affects out though, feelings, behavior and personalities.

By the mid-20th century, there were other major forces in psychology like "Humanist Psychology", which focuses on nurturing personal growth; "Cognitive Science" and "Neuroscience", all of which contributed their own unique takes on the study of mind.


Psychology:
Modern day definition of psychology "the study of behavior and mental processes", is a nice amalgamation that pulls from all these different schools of thought.
It recognizes the need for observing and recording behavior, but it also gives credit to our mental processes, what we think and feel and believe.
Psychology is an integrative science and while there are different school of thoughts & theories, the essence of the discipline has everything to do with creating different ways of asking interesting questions and attempting to answer them through all kinds of data-gathering methods.
The human mind is complicated.
There is no single way to effectively crack it open; it must be pried at from all sides.


Harvard astronomer Owen Gingerich has gazed into the distant horizon of space, and even he has acknowledged that the human brain is by far the most complex physical object known to us in the entire cosmos, and we all get to have one!

Correction on the etymology and origin of the word Psychology, it's orgin is Ancient Greek. 

1650s, "study of the soul," from Modern Latin psychologia, probably coined mid-16c. in Germany by Melanchthon from Latinized form of Greek psykhē "breath, spirit, soul" (see psyche) + logia "study of" (see -logy). Meaning "study of the mind" first recorded 1748, from Christian Wolff's "Psychologia empirica" (1732); main modern behavioral sense is from early 1890s.

Do you know a psychological trick people use to manipulate others?
Here’s a good one, and you’ll never realize it’s a manipulative tactic.

When someone has a complaint or an issue with you—such as a higher-up, sometimes they’ll throw in something like “everyone has mentioned it”, or “everyone feels that way about you.”

Of course, they won’t tell you exactly WHO else feels this way, or exactly who has brought it up. They’ll refuse to tell you that part.

So then you stew about it. You wonder what’s being said or why everybody seems to be in on this and you’re the last to know. You’ll start to second-guess yourself and your actions and replay conversations, etc. It can drive you nuts.

In reality, nobody has said anything. Your manipulator has just made you paranoid.

And the best part—the icing on the cake—once they have you feeling paranoid—THEY OFFER TO HELP YOU. Because you know, they care. And they don’t want to see anything bad happen to you.

Don’t buy into this load of bull. Trust your instincts and get as far away from this manipulator as you can.

Covert hypnosis:
When a person is the victim of covert hypnosis he doesn't know that he is being hypnotized, this makes him more open to questions and commands. For example if a person under covert hypnosis is asked, "tell me all your secrets", they will comply with little to no resistance. If a person under voluntary hypnosis is asked the same thing, they will refuse to answer.
Every year in America and Canada thousands of people are victims of illegal covert hypnosis, and 99.9% will never know that they were covertly hypnotized.
The "official" reason for illegal covert hypnosis is to find out if people with antisocial behavior are a threat or have committed a crime. But most instances of illegal covert hypnosis are done to steal private knowledge from the victims mind. Once hypnotized the victim can be asked any question, or given any command, then the victim is programmed with a word or phrase that will put him instantly in a hypnotic state, finally he is told to forget what happened, and wake up. He will not remember being hypnotized for the rest of his life.

The individual whom has just presented this video is pretty deceptive especially with the self admission of "I don't know" when it's abundantly clear that he knows exactly how the human mind works.

That's why he presented this video in the manner he did and by that I mean, he spoke at such a speed that for the overwhelming majority of his audience to fully know and (understand) what he's indeed said it will mean them having to play this video back over and over and pause it at particular points so they can conduct their own further investigations.

Anyone who says human psychology is complex isn't being forthcoming or completely honest with their audience because human psychology is the easiest subject anyone can study.

Let me give you an example, when all of us were born this includes myself we only knew biological actions or instinctual actions if you will, factually what's culminated in all of us becoming the individuals we all are today is nothing more than repetitive iterations of information which have been locked onto our subconscious minds and of course the way in which that is accomplished is via repetition by both reward or feelings of pleasure or trauma or feelings of pain.

It's no more complex than that.

Humans along with all creatures have what is known as an endocannabinoid system and this system is what is responsible for stimulating conditions for new cell growth within the brains of any and all creatures which have them (even if we can't distinguish a particular creature as having what we think of as a brain in no way denotes they don't have one).
Any and all creatures with an endocannabinoid system does in fact have a brain.

Now the reason for this system as I've said is specifically to promote new cell growth within the brain because as we all know the place which houses the brain is in continual growth from the moment of birth right through to death, hence the saying "you learn something new every day"

What we're not told is how the subconscious mind processes information and there are indeed differences between your conscious and subconscious mind.
For example, your conscious mind rests or stops if you will and this takes place when you go to sleep, but your subconscious mind never stops from the moment you're born until the day you die, instances of the subconscious mind completely taking control over the unconscious mind and body can be seen in individuals whom sleep walk or sleep talk.
Of course we can all study ourselves and see times when our own subconscious mind takes control over our conscious mind and body, for example when performing tasks such as soldering complex electronic circuits or even cleaning our homes in complete silence.
These are ideal conditions for yours and indeed my own subconscious to take control and that's when it will play a song in our minds which we believe we like and this results in us either singing, tapping our feet or even dancing and this can and does predominantly take place when in either deep concentration or performing methodical tasks.

As you said psychology initially started as a study of the soul and evolved into the study of human behavior and mental process. Today with the advent of AI, machines are able to mimic human cognition. Just as human learning machine learning involves induction through cognition. Given the correct data set and processing capabilities, machines carry out any task with much less error and in much less time. Recently Google reversed engineered a neural network (trained to detect birds in an image) to draw a picture of an image, therefore, emulating creativity. With such great strides being made in the field of AI how important it is to introduce a dedicated field in psychology to study the behavior and cognitive process of intelligent machines? More importantly, do you think it is time to rethink the definition of psychology factoring in these intelligent machines?

Video is completely USELESS for all you actually wanting to master psychology.

Here’s why:

Most important factor is that nobody actually knows how in depth the human mind can go and can sustain. For example I may have 10 years of traveling the world, partying, family activity’s as well, but how much of that will I actually remember and sustain in my brain? And is it possible to keep it all inside , how much more can my mind hold is there a limit? Etc..

Therefore do not waste time on watching a lecture on famous people in history who spoke about psychology. Because you need to master within yourself to make it come to life. Otherwise your wasting your time on a history lesson. Plain and simple .

I would tell you how to start your journey.

It starts with yourself, monitoring your daily behavior not conscious but unconscious, meaning go thru your day with your normal activities. By the end of the day when you are in bed in silence and ready to shut down for the night. Begin the process of observation and reasoning in your mind. Why did I do this ceremony thing today? , what did I gain out of it?, could I have done without?, was it good or bad?, etc.. study yourself . After this which should take some time till you gain wisdom. Then you can move on to people comparing them to you and comparing the differences etc..

Again there is so much to be said and done.

But do not waste your time here in these type of videos.

I used to watch these videos for fun when I was in high school, but now that I’m in college taking a legit psychology class I appreciate this series more than ever!

A fascinating video that truly helps us try to grasp the extent of the complexity of the human mind. I've always been curious about how our mind functions and this was a great start to this journey of discovery about the science of psychology. A truly commendable aspect of this field is that all people practicing psychology did not confine themselves within any rigid schools of thoughts and came forward with vastly differing theories which all attempted to unlock parts of our brain and how it functions. The amazing part is that all these theories are still extant today and have been the building block of modern psychological practices.
Another interesting aspect of this video was the in-depth analysis of how Sigmund Freud came up with his theories. All of his theories had always seemed a tad bit shocking but he was definitely a great thinker and truly revolutionized this field as he didn't allow his ideas to be circumscribed by the general thinking of people around him.

I have a tip to Memorize things quicker that I think most others know, but just in case...

During your study sessions, chew some gum. Make sure to remember the flavor (try to use something you eat normally, or something that's memorable because it's unusual to you). Then, chew the same flavor at your exam or whenever you need it.

Because brains associate memories to several things (A feeling of disorientation when sick, pain after falling, or perhaps just something you saw while learning.), it will translate the memory to that particular flavor. Chewing gum will also help with stress, since your brain says "Oh, you're eating? Well, we must not be in danger." and calms the nerves.

Psychology is a science of behaviour and mental processes.psychology mainly takes the following questions
#1. how humans commit genocide or torture other humans
#2. what is mental illness
#3. what is consciousness
psychology gives a detailed picture how our brains behave the way we do even though we don't want it to about thinking processes and so on.

Sigmund Freud theory:
theories to build an idea of personality dreams childhood schools of psychology
#1. structuralism
unit for the Structuralists were the elementary elements of consciousness.
you trained an observer to reflect on and analyze their mental experiences
#2. functionalism
study of the function rather than the structure of consciousness was interested in how our minds adapt to our changing environment.
#3. behaviourism
heavy emphasis on observable behaviour
much easier to study than concepts such as motivation, emotion, intelligence, etc.

1.
In order to learn to speak English like native speakers I must learn to think in English before. The technique for that is very simple. When I'm walking in the street I should begin to think in English without translating my thoughts in Russian. How can I achieve that? Well, I must start with a simple sentence like that: "I want to think in English". Then, if nothing comes to my head, I must repeat the sentence. I must repeat the sentence while some other sentence will come to my head It may be something like that: "I want to think in English but how can I do it? I know some words and I can connect the words to each other. What words do I know..?

2.
Every day I can begin with the sentence: I want to think in English. I have to imagine a way of the thinking process in which I could go in different possible directions for some minutes. Every good step that I will make will be noted as a new level in the game. For example, the first point is: I want to think in English. The second may be: everything, what I need for thinking, is time. How much time can I spend for this kind of thinking per day? It's a good question. If I want to get a good result it must be one or two hours at least. How can i organize it? How much time do I spend for the internet every day? If I could use half of this time for thinking, I would get enough.

3.
I want to think in English. Where would I come today? Where would I come in a month? In a year? If I think every day trying to write down the process of thinking and focusing on some issue within a month, I will be able to figure out what thinking in English is like. If I concentrate on the issue during a year, I will be able to use English in the process of thinking without efforts. What prospects does it offer? I will be able to listen to everything that I can find on the internet in English. It is the same with reading. Also I will be able to write. It gives me an opportunity to communicate with everyone I want. I can master thinking everywhere. Every free five minutes I can get to it.

I simply do not understand this field of study, let me ask something, how can one person hope to truly understand whats inside the mind of another? yes. you can ask them psych, and personality specific question, yes you can try studying their behaviors in certain stressful or leisurely situations, Yes you can study brain activity while someone undergoes certain physical and mental stress tests. But when it comes down to it we can never fully understand that which we cannot see, hear, feel, or experience for ourselves, people lie when asked certain questions, people themselves sometimes don't understand what they want for example there are many students in colleges and universities who are taking majors they are unsure of they do not know what they want out of life so if they don't know with exclusive access to their own minds how could someone outside that space possibly hope to figure it out see what i mean? this applies to a multitude of other factors that affect human behaviors, speech, reasoning, etc. even Freud's method is pure conjecture unable to truly be proven although his methodology for studying the human mind may seem like it explains how humans behaive almost perfectly, its still just a theory and just because something fits does not mean its this full proof method, we can make any theory fit our needs to rationalize what we want but in the end as i said it cannot be proven.  however i'm not a psychologist so there maybe a perfectly reasonable explanation as to how someone can accomplish such things, if you have one please  i am simply looking for an explanation that is all.

as a psychologist I find it outrageous that behaviorism is presented like just another phase of psychology that faded out in the `60. Within behaviorism psychology gets as close to hard science as possible by experimenting and replicating the results over and over until this day. It is not at all nice and cute and we don`t like to hear that we are conditioned into doing things so easily but science is cold and objective and does not really care about hurting anybody`s feelings...Skinner`s "Behavior of Organisms" , and later on "Verbal Behavior", did for psychology what Darwin`s "On the Origin of Species" did for biology.

I do understand that this is a short video meant to appeal to a broad audience but still ...the people involved in this channel (and the related ones as well) post in "science nerds" and try to make science cool for kids - which is a great thing don`t get me wrong - but they keep promoting the senzational trends going on in psychology today (more that half of the studies fail replication http://www.nature.com/news/over-half-of-psychology-studies-fail-reproducibility-test-1.18248). This is a disservice to science in general and to the science of psychology in particular.

Behaviorism did not fade out in the `60. It is very alive and well today and has made such great and amazing discoveries during the years that have effective applications: from mental patients to medical patients to weight loss to business to public policies. It is a shame to disregard it just because it is not telling us what we want to hear...that is very unscientific.

I can simplify this concept for about 75% of all psychology students.

If you're taking a BA in psychology, which well more than 75% do, then don't worry about your marks. If you're not in a coma for both the midterm(s) and exam then it's not humanly possible to get less than an A- and you'll only get that if you showed up piss drunk and passed out 20 minutes in. Here are some sample BA psychology questions, and yes ALL tests are ALWAYS multiple choice with options seldom reaching as far as "D":

1) What comes after day?
a) Christmas Tree
b) night
c) 17

2) How do you spell "yes"?
a) y-e-s
b) s-y-e

3) How useful is a BA in psychology?
a) Not at all

4) Spell your name correctly anywhere on this entire examination. Or don't, either way it's worth full marks.

To call Psychology a science, then associate Freud with science does a great disservice to Psych and what it means to be called a Science :P
From what I've learnt, the majority of modern psych is actually trying to operate as the hard sciences (and therefore be labeled as scientists, and not just psychologists), and to do that they've distanced themselves from Freud (and like you mentioned, hate him and think his ideas actually set psych back). I don't know if I would call Freud monumental; maybe for his time, but he quickly went out of style. To go the way of the lobotomy as it were xD
For example most psych profs I talk with wish his ideas would stay forgotten, as we are now able to quantify and actually measure/replicate aspects of the psyche thanks to tech and non-Freudian ways of thinking.
It's like how Astronomers/Physicists treat Aristotle but to a much greater degree, b/c at least Aristotle pioneered some fields still in use.

To anyone interested in an introduction to Psychology as a subject, in a very manageable and easy format, I highly recommend the following two 'graphic' books;

'Introducing Psychology; A Graphic Guide' Nigel C. Benson, London, 2007, Icon Books Ltd. ISBN:978-184046-852-6

and, from DK; 'The Psychology Book'
a collaboration from 6 insightful contributors. DK London, 2012. ISBN 978-1-4053-9124-5

All the main schools of thought, approaches, key figures and research techniques are introduced in a perfectly illustrated, straight forward, and engaging way.

mi resumen del video (si les sirve de algo):
-La psicología es muy diversa porque: por las preguntas que plantea, los métodos que aplica y las diferentes escuelas de pensamiento y disciplinas. 
-Estructuralismo, funcionalismo y psicoanálisis. 
-Psicología científica (1879) Alemania —>  Dr. Wilheln Wundt estableció laboratorio de psicología, con un alumno suyo juntó la química y física, hacían preguntas a sus pacientes de que sentían frente a ciertos estímulos. Como cada quien es diferente las respuestas también y el estructuralismo duró poco. 
-William James, EU, se pregunto porque hacemos lo que hacemos. Funcionalismo, basado en Darwin). 
-Freud y la terapia del habla. Inconsciente y psicoanálisis.  IMPORTANTE: a partir de esto se creó la idea de que un paciente se puede curar, no nada mas diagnosticar.
-Conductivismo: Pavlov, Watson y Skinner. Comportamiento observable. 
-S.XX: Psicología humanista, ciencia cognitiva y neurociencia.
-Definición formal: el estudio/ciencia de comportamiento y los procesos mentales
-Ciencia integradora, preguntas interesantes que se pueden responder de cualquier método que recopile información. Debe investigarse de todas partes.

Psychology isn't a 'faux science', it is just more biased and unreliable as a source of knowledge IF it doesn't include calculative analyses (in terms of values like numbers, which goes into neurology, basically). Having high knowledge of psychology has many benefits. This doesn't really prove any points, but I have the psychoanalytical gift of correctly being able to tell what people are 'thinking' (it is more complex than that) but this only works from time to time, and it probably works due to an abnormality of my own brain. Even if you excel at a certain science, to demean another science (more for its focus than its methods) is unwise as you should realise that all sciences strongly connect to and explain each other, although I believe that physics is the biggest field of them all. To disregard any science - in this society, at least - completely reduces our chances in expanding knowledge and innovation. I'm seventeen years old, and I excel very highly in all scientific areas, which is actually a rare ability. I am able to realise exactly how important each science is, and that it is very unwise to disregard any science as unworthy of studying. I can understand why many people do not like psychology, as it is very inaccurate. However, without it, society would not have been as highly developed as it is today.

He mentioned so many great thinkers but not the Buddha, who had taught (in my view) the most well-grounded "theory" of the workings of the mind, because he saw how the mind worked himself — not through divine intervention or thinking, but through conscious observation of the mind and its phenomena which arise due to causes and effects. The questions asked at 1:36 can easily be answered by somebody who knows the basic workings of the mind... For example humans commit genocide for a number of (specific) reasons but it these boil down to the mind (due its lack of wisdom) giving rise to the unwholesome qualities of greed, hatred, and delusion. These things arise due to the mind's ignorance of the truth of reality: all things are changing, suffering arises when we attach to things, and everything is empty of self or inherent existence (because everything is conditioned by causes). Ignorance also translates to us not seeing the harm which is inherent in unwholesome actions. If we want to stop behaving badly, we should start reflecting on our actions and contemplating the pleasant and unpleasant results of engaging in them — that's wisdom, the pure awareness which lies in the heart of all of us and (for the ignorant) is obscured like the moon behind clouds. Unconscious mental phenomena are simply that: unconscious. In layman's terms, we're just unaware of these mental phenomena. But the Buddha and all of his disciples were able to train the mind to be mindful of mental phenomena — which is proof that these phenomena are totally observable in the here and now, which means that anybody can do it if they just start dedicating themselves to knowing things as they are.

I wouldn't call psychology a "Science" at all. Hank said it- it's a melting pot of many, many ideas, most of which have nothing to do with the scienfitic method and are not supported by independent fields of scientifc study.

Just inside clinical psychology we see psychoanlaisis is completely subjective, Freud pretty much pulled it out of his (admitedly genious) ass, as he listened to the issues his patients described. While it does have its merit, it is not science. At all.

And then we have humanism, which pretty much said "Fuck science" and instead focused on philosophical principles that could not be tested, created theories and models that, not only were badly defined if at all defined, but where based on intuition and experience almost completely.

And don't get me started on transpersonal psychology, which is just a mash-up of humanist psychology, new age, budhism and pseudo-science. A badly made mash up too.

With the description of the murderer from the recipient's dreams the police were able to locate the criminal and put him to jail.

FACTUAL ERROR!  Hank said about the visual cortex at about 8:30 in that the "...right cortex processes input from the left eye and vice versa."  It's not that simple.  The right visual cortex process input from the right side of EACH retina which projects as the LEFT VISUAL FIELD while the left cortex receives input from the left halves of each eye which project as the right hemifield.  So each side of the visual cortex receives input from BOTH EYES, not just one as suggested.

I've loved much of your earlier work, but I'm deeply disappointed in this. The errors are epic. Wundt was no structuralist (and you mispronounced Leipzig).Titchener created Structuralism out a small sliver of Wundt's approach. Titchener's formal introspection was nothing like lying on a couch delivering up impressions to a nearby therapist (as in your illustration). William James was influential upon Functionalism, to be sure, but wasn't really a member of the "school" himself, and had moved on to other things by the time it really arose. Skinner's Behavior of Organisms was a fairly late event in the development of Behaviorism, which had begun more than 20 years earlier (Watson, Hull, Tolman). And there is way too much emphasis on Freud, who was highly influential on American psychiatry, but not so much on psychology. In any case, ideas about unconscious mentality hardly originated with Freud. They were floating around lots of German philosophy at the time, and had already been a formal part of both Helmholtz's and Wundt's scientific theories.

As someone who has spent the last five years studying psychology in depth, this was not only a letdown but embarrassing to the field.  If you're going to mention some things about Freud, might as well finish the last half of the sentence, right? Freud came up with the idea of having patients lie down on a couch while he sat behind them ... to induce anxiety, which he thought was the result of unresolved conflict between the id, ego, and superego (by the way, that is what ALL Psy 101 students learn about Freud/his basis for treatment, so that would've been useful to throw in). Freud's counterpart developed the "talking cure" ... Freud took it.  Freud's delve into the "talking cure" was a matter of attempting to figure out why those with hysteria had it. Hint: he got it right; it was that these women had been sexually abused as children. So, what does Freud do with this information? He refuses to believe that it could be going on in such a pandemic fashion that he, instead, decides to view all of these cases of rape as the patient putting forth their innermost sexual desires. Thus began that practice with Freud. Yes, he came up with some good things. His theory on defense mechanisms is spot on and widely accepted. But, most other things are utter crock. If you are going to talk about Freud, please discuss him in a manner in which people can imagine him complexly, opposed to simply glorifying him. Also, psychoanalysis is still not widely practiced; it is still practiced in some small sects on the east coast and in San Francisco. Also also, lumping neuroscience and cognitive psychology together doesn't make sense due to their being completely different schools of thought.

I think that this venerates Freud much too much.
Sure, he was unique in that he took a developmental approach to psychology, and he had the concept of an "unconscious mind", but his concept of the unconscious mind turned out to be almost entirely wrong! There are many processes in the brain that are ongoing without our conscious awareness of them, but relatively many of them revolve around thinking "is this image a face or just some splattered paint, hmm better go with face" and not "FOOD FOOD SEX SEX SEX SEX-WITH-YOUR-MOTHER SEX PENIS PENIS VAGINA-PENIS SEX FOOD SEX".
He based his theories off of his own experiences as opposed to experiments, studies, or other objective, verifiable tests. 
And his psychoanalysis was certainly an improvement over chaining patients to beds, but it was based off of the idea that one can "let off steam", or engage in violent or highly emotional behaviors in order to decrease the frequency of those violent or highly emotional behaviors, when in fact, it is the opposite. Engaging in violent or highly emotional behaviors has been shown to increase the frequency of just such behaviors.
In short, why not mention the simple fact that Freud was wrong about nearly everything?

While I must say that Skinner was wrong about a lot of things, (for instance, that thoughts and feelings are mere correlations between behaviours and consequences of behaviours: this is absurd, as if this were the case, by natural selection, thoughts and feelings would die out. Feelings and thoughts must play a causal role in behaviour, otherwise they would die out) it is a common misconception that he put babies in Skinner boxes; in reality, when he put his baby daughter to sleep, it was in a crib used to keep her at a comfortable temperature (like awwwwwwww), not condition her behaviour.(Google the name "Deborah Buzan". This is the name of Skinners daughter. The first Result I got was a guardian article written by her, insisting that she was never a "lab rat".
Having read his book "Walden 2", While I must say his science was obviously flawed, his aims were admirable: the betterment of the human condition.

There are a hundred things I could ask you included in this course, but in terms of impact, I'd really like to advocate for two topics in particular: Eating disorders and Schizophrenia (including hallucinations in the sane). The former a lot of people know about, but often just assume things like anorexia happen because of vanity. When you get into the science, that's mostly not the case - there are genetics, physical triggers (see: the Minnesota Starvation Study) and mental adaptations to a new average body shape through exposure to photoshoped images. With Schizophrenia... this is one of the things that really crushes me. Especially in Western societies, Hollywood's stereotype of psychotic killers with multiple personalities is really all people know of Schizophrenia. It's so inaccurate, and considering how common this condition is (1/100), it really needs addressing. I'd love to see some focus on the spectrum from low schizotypy to diagnosis of psychosis and an illustration of how sometimes these things aren't as clean cut as 'this person is well and this one is insane'.

Wow, this was long. I apologise, and hope you made it through! If you're ever looking for suggestions (I realise mine are completely unsolicited, sorry ^^;) or a hand with any research, I'd love to lend a hand.

Thank you again for this!

Uh oh, Hank mixed up Greek & Latin. Anything that ends in -logy is usually Greek. In this case Psycho is from psyche or ΨΥΧΗ, which means soul, or originally breath, from the verb psychō "to blow." Ah Freud. He had some great ideas that really helped, but then he started also creating theories that were bad. He started off so well. Unconscious thought was genius. Then he started to use introspection to come up with ideas about how everyone's minds work and that isn't scientific and isn't an effective way to really understand all minds.

On a different note, Wundt did not use introspection with other people. His main method of study was the same as Freud's, self-introspection. He created the first school of thought and taught all his students to study the mind by having people simply think about things and write down their thoughts and revelations on their own. One of his students then moved to America and started his slightly different school of thought using Guided introspection where the introspection was led by an observer who also took notes. The use of proper scientific techniques did not develop for a while and was very controversial with the first psychologists.

I don't understand the question on free will. To me there is only one legitimate answer to this, and therefor it can't be considered a question.
Yes we have free will, to presume otherwise would be absurd.
1. Without free will we could not form our own thoughts, these too would be purely the result of a complex bio-chemical set of reactions. Our control of our thoughts would be an illusion. It's difficult for me to phrase how absurd that would be, it'd be the end of reason. As reason itself would degrade to yet another illusion. 
2. Occams razor while never proof for any theory, still stands. The idea that free will is an illusion requires more assumptions and is more complex than the idea that free will is truly real.

[Psych nerd alert, we talked about this in class recently.]
Anna O. was actually put under hypnosis (which Freud was against, though it triggered his idea of the unconscious mind.) She would come in every week with a physical symptom (paralysis of a muscle in her neck that made it impossible to turn her head and extreme dehydration due to an inability to drink water among others), she was put under hypnosis and would remember a traumatic event she had repressed that was linked to her symptoms. Then after being taken out of hypnosis she would be perfectly fine.
She described the process as "chimney sweeping". She also later outed herself (her real name was Bertha Pappenheim) went on to become a prominent social worker, and was also one of the founders of The League of Jewish Women.
Also, by the time Freud died he had a fake lower jaw. He had to take it out and clean it to keep from getting an infection on top of the cancer.

Hi Hank

In the first two minutes of the video you discuss of lots of things under the label of 'psychology,' when I think they're more properly called 'philosophy'.  This conflation makes sense: modern psychology grew out of philosophy, and the larger part of the history of psychology before Freud and Jung is chiefly philosophical (e.g. Aristotle, Hume(!), Kant, Nietzsche, etc.).  It was only about 90 years ago that departments of psychology at major universities became independent of departments of philosophy.  Before this division philosophy departments in the West were usually titled 'Department of Philosophy and Psychology'.  

I point this out in the interest of accuracy and in the hopes that there might some day be a CrashCourse course on philosophy.

Cheers!
